templates: We've seen safety scores decline this cycle. What specific factors do you think contributed to this? What early warning signs might you have missed?
When safety suffers, what are the first things to deteriorate? Think about communication, documentation, escalation pathways.
Several teams saw safety impacts. What's the relationship between the decisions you made and the safety outcomes you experienced?
Equity scores dropped for some teams. Who might be falling through the gaps when services are under pressure?
When you tighten access or prioritise cases, what assumptions are you making about who can wait? What are the risks?
How do we balance clinical prioritisation with ensuring everyone can access care? Where's the line?
Staff wellbeing has taken a hit across multiple teams. What are the early warning signs of burnout, and when do you intervene?
You're seeing increased sickness and low morale. What's the cost of not investing in your team? What happens next year?
How do you protect your workforce when the demand never stops? What's sustainable vs what's just surviving?
System resilience has decreased. What makes a service fragile vs robust? Think about dependencies, single points of failure.
When resilience drops, what happens the next time you face a shock? How much buffer do you have left?
You've burned through your reserves – financial, staff energy, goodwill. What's your recovery plan?
Backlogs are growing. At what point does a waiting list become a safety issue? How do you know?
You're rationing appointments. Who decides which women wait? What criteria are you using, and are they equitable?
A backlog isn't just numbers – it's women waiting, worrying, potentially deteriorating. How do you manage that ethically?
DNA rates are rising. Is this a system problem or a patient problem? What's your hypothesis?
When women don't attend, what are we not seeing? Think about barriers – practical, cultural, psychological.
You can send more reminders, but what if the problem is trust, or appointment times, or childcare? What else could you try?
An incident occurred this cycle. Root cause analysis: was it a person, a process, or a system design issue?
When incidents happen under pressure, what's the learning culture like? Do staff feel safe to report and reflect?
How do you prevent this from happening again without adding more burden to an already stretched team?
This team spent heavily on capacity. What were you trying to achieve? Did it work, or did you just spread the same staff thinner?
You prioritised clinical access over other needs. What was the trade-off? What didn't you invest in, and what was the consequence?
You've invested heavily in cash-intensive solutions. Is this sustainable? What happens when the budget runs out?
Short-term fixes often cost more in the long run. Are you building dependency on expensive temporary solutions?
You've asked a lot of your team this cycle – audits, reviews, new processes. What's the cumulative burden?
Change fatigue is real. Are you building sustainable new practices, or are you adding to the to-do list?
Your safety improved, but equity dropped. Who did you deprioritise to achieve that? Was it explicit or accidental?
Triage is essential, but it creates winners and losers. How do you make those decisions transparent and defensible?
There's a tension here between clinical risk and access equity. Where's your team's line? What's your ethical framework?
You've invested in remote monitoring. Implementation risk is high – tech issues, adoption, data overload. What's your mitigation plan?
Digital solutions can improve access, but they can also create new inequities. Who might be excluded? Older women? Those without smartphones?
Remote monitoring means more data. Do you have the capacity to respond to it? What's your escalation protocol?
This is a long-term investment. You won't see full benefits this cycle. How will you sustain the team through the implementation phase?
You've used bank/agency staff. Quick fix, but what's the impact on continuity of care? On team morale?
Agency staff cost 2-3x permanent staff. If you keep doing this, what's the budget impact next year?
Temporary staff don't know your systems, your women, your team culture. What safeguards are in place?
Is this a one-off pressure response, or are you papering over a structural workforce problem?
You've protected learning time. That's capacity you're not using for clinical work. What's the trade-off worth?
Investment in staff development pays off, but not immediately. What are you expecting to see in future cycles?
Protected time signals you value the team. How does that affect retention, morale, quality?
You tightened triage. Who now waits longer? What's the risk of missing someone who deteriorates while waiting?
Prioritisation is clinically sound, but how do you communicate this to women who feel deprioritised?
You've drawn a line between 'urgent' and 'routine'. How confident are you in that line? What if you get it wrong?
As the diabetes specialist: What specific risks did you see emerging? Were glucose monitoring protocols followed?
From a diabetes perspective: What's the relationship between workload pressure and hypoglycaemia/DKA risk?
Specialist midwife lens: When you're stretched, what aspects of diabetes care get dropped first?
As the diabetes specialist: Are all women getting equal access to education, monitoring technology, and consultant review?
Specialist midwife perspective: Which groups are most likely to have poor glycaemic control, and are we reaching them?
Think about equity in diabetes care: Language barriers, health literacy, digital access. Where are the gaps?
As clinical lead: What governance arrangements need strengthening? Who owns risk in your service?
Clinical lead perspective: When you review this incident, what systems failed? What would you change?
From a leadership lens: How do you balance psychological safety (staff can report errors) with accountability?
As clinical lead: You're responsible for service sustainability. What's your red line? When do you escalate to senior management?
Clinical leadership question: Are you building a service that depends on individual heroism, or robust systems?
From a leadership perspective: How do you maintain standards when you're permanently firefighting?
Workforce lead: What are the retention risks here? How many of your team are updating their CVs right now?
From a capacity perspective: You can recruit more staff, but can you retain them if the culture doesn't change?
Workforce lens: What's the cost of losing experienced staff? How long to train a replacement?
Workforce perspective: Agency is a symptom of a deeper problem. What's the root cause you're not addressing?
From a capacity planning view: If you spent the agency money on permanent staff and training, what would change?
Workforce lead question: How does using agency affect your permanent staff's morale and sense of value?
Service pathway view: Where are the bottlenecks? Is it referrals in, triage, appointment slots, or follow-up?
From a pathway perspective: If you redesigned the service from scratch, what would you do differently?
Pathway lead: Are you measuring the right things? What metrics would tell you the pathway is working well?
Service pathway perspective: DNAs are waste. What's the root cause analysis? Is it the appointment system, or something deeper?
From a pathway view: What would a woman-centered booking system look like? What would you need to change?
Pathway lead question: Are you designing services for staff convenience or patient needs?
Every decision has trade-offs. What did you choose NOT to do this cycle? Was that explicit or implicit?
You can't win all four pillars at once. Which one did you sacrifice, and why? Was it a conscious choice?
Looking at your decisions holistically: Is there a pattern? Are you consistently prioritising one dimension over others?
If you could redo this cycle, what would you change? Not with hindsight about outcomes, but about your decision-making process?
What did you learn about your own biases and assumptions? What surprised you?
How well did your team communicate? Where was there disagreement, and how did you resolve it?
Think about the women in your service. Did you consider their voices when making decisions? How?
What data would you want to have that you didn't have? What would you do with it?
Who wasn't at the table when you made these decisions? Service users? Junior staff? Other specialties?
Compare your strategy to other teams. What did they do differently? Why might that have worked for them?
If you were facilitating a team that's struggling, what advice would you give them based on your experience?
What's transferable from this simulation to your real-world service? What's the first thing you'd change?
Walk through the incident. What were the contributing factors? Think Swiss cheese model – what holes aligned?
If you were doing a serious incident review, what questions would you ask? Who would you speak to?
What's the difference between an individual error and a system failure? Which is this?
How do you support the staff involved in an incident while also learning from it?
Equity isn't just about equal treatment – it's about equitable outcomes. What groups had worse outcomes this cycle?
Think about social determinants: poverty, language, housing, digital access. How did your decisions interact with these?
What's the difference between equality (same for all) and equity (fair distribution)? Which did you prioritize?
How do you measure equity? What data would you collect to understand if you're reaching everyone?
Your staff are exhausted. What would a sustainable service model look like? Be specific – how would it differ from now?
Burnout has stages: enthusiasm, stagnation, frustration, apathy. Where is your team, and what's the intervention?
What creates moral injury in healthcare? When have you felt it? How do you prevent it in your team?
If your best midwife said 'I'm leaving', what would you do to change their mind? Would it work?
Resilience is the ability to absorb shocks. What shocks could you absorb now? What would break you?
Think about your service as infrastructure: bridges, buildings. Where are the weak points? What needs reinforcing?
How much redundancy do you have? If one person is off sick, does the whole system fail?
What would a 'stress test' of your service look like? What scenarios would you plan for?
Digital implementation is hard. What's your change management plan? Who are your champions? Who are your skeptics?
Think about the implementation curve: early adopters, early majority, late majority, laggards. Where's your team?
What training and support do staff need? What training do women need? Who provides it?
How do you know if the technology is working? What metrics? What feedback loops?
You've spent heavily. What's the business case for the next financial year? How do you justify this to commissioners?
Short-term spending can prevent long-term costs (litigation, poor outcomes). How do you quantify that?
What's the opportunity cost? What else could you have done with that money?
Are you shifting costs or solving problems? Be honest.
What does good governance look like in a diabetes midwifery service? Clear roles, escalation, audit, feedback?
How mature is your governance? Reactive (fixing problems) or proactive (preventing them)?
Who owns clinical risk? Who owns service risk? Where does accountability sit?
What's the relationship between governance and bureaucracy? When does necessary oversight become burden?
Most incidents involve communication failure. Where did communication break down this cycle?
Think about handovers: midwife to midwife, midwife to doctor, team to team. What's your most vulnerable handover point?
How do you ensure critical information doesn't get lost? What's the signal vs noise problem?
What role does hierarchy play? Do junior staff feel they can speak up? How do you know?
What metrics are you tracking in your real service? Are they the right ones? What's missing?
Outcome metrics (what happened) vs process metrics (what did you do). Which do you focus on? Why?
How do you avoid gaming the system? When targets become goals, what gets distorted?
What data do you wish you had? What would it tell you?
Leadership under pressure: How do you stay calm when everything's on fire? How do you model that for your team?
What's your leadership style when under pressure? Command and control? Collaborative? Adaptive? Is it effective?
How do you balance optimism (we can fix this) with realism (this is really hard)? Where's the line?
When do you ask for help? When do you escalate? What stops you?
Think systems, not silos. How does your diabetes service interact with booking, labour ward, postnatal, community? Where are the weak points?
Unintended consequences: What decision did you make that had effects you didn't predict?
Feedback loops: When things go well, what reinforces that? When things go badly, what makes it worse?
Complex systems have emergent properties. You can't predict everything. How do you build in adaptive capacity?
Co-production: What would it look like to design this service WITH women, not FOR them?
Who are the experts? Clinicians? Managers? Or the women living with diabetes every day?
How do you gather and act on user feedback? Do you just ask, or do you genuinely change practice?
What would a service user say if they were in this room right now? What question would they ask you?
This is a simulation. What's different in reality? What constraints exist that aren't in the game?
What's one thing you'll do differently on Monday because of this session?
What would you need – resources, permission, support – to actually implement your best ideas?
Who needs to hear the insights from this session? How will you share them?
